item.title: Apollo to Tap Rich, Retail Clients in Asia for Asset Growth
item.description: Apollo Global Management Inc. said high-net-worth clients and access to retail investors are the biggest opportunities in Asia for growth in the coming years.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Du, Sonali Basak, Yvonne Man

item.title: Bain, KKR Said to Be Second-Round Bidders for Sapporo Unit
item.description: Bain Capital, KKR & Co. and Lone Star are among investment firms that have advanced to the second round of bidding for the real estate unit of Sapporo Holdings Ltd., according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ryo Horiuchi, Takako Taniguchi

media:content.media:description: Yebisu Garden Place Photographer: Smith Collection/Gado/Getty Images

item.title: Chinese Stocks Advance as Preliminary Trade Deal Eases Tensions
item.description: Chinese stocks rose on Wednesday, after the world’s two largest economies agreed on a plan to reduce trade tensions following a two-day meeting in London.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Lin Zhu, Winnie Hsu

item.title: Stocks Edge Up, Futures Dip After China-US Talks: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian stocks posted modest gains after US and Chinese officials struck an optimistic tone at the end of two days of talks aimed at defusing trade tensions. Shares in mainland China stood out.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy, Winnie Hsu

media:content.media:description: US and Chinese flags in the entrance during trade talks at Lancaster House in London, UK, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025. Talks between the US and China extended later into their second day in London, with financial markets on edge as the world’s largest economies negotiate over key tech and industrial exports and deescalating their trade war.

item.title: Singapore-Backed Realty Company Bets on India Entertainment Boom
item.description: Prestige Estates Projects Ltd., which ranks among India’s top five real estate developers by market value, is looking to sell more entertainment and dining spaces in malls while cutting back on apparel retailers, a top official said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Ajith

media:content.media:description: Invitees enjoy screening at the new rooftop drive-in theatre in Mumbai on November 5, 2021. (Photo by Punit PARANJPE / AFP) (Photo by PUNIT PARANJPE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Apollo's Michelini on Japan Insurance, Consumer Trends
item.description: Apollo Global Management's Matthew Michelini says the Japanese insurance industry is "really interesting" right now and adds that "accessing retail consumers is one of the biggest opportunity sets." He discusses his views in a conversation with Sonali Basak at the Bloomberg Invest conference in Hong Kong. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Being a Bully on Trade Won’t Work Longer Term, Lagarde Warns
item.description: There’s no longer-term advantage to being a bully on global commerce, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

item.title: Gold Gains Even as US and China Agree to Ease Trade War
item.description: Gold gained even after the US and China said they had agreed on a plan to ease trade tensions during talks in London.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: The Euro Struggles to Win Over Czechs Going Slow on Adoption
item.description: The Czech central bank governor touted the benefits of his country’s currency, saying that the koruna puts it in a better position to moderate price-growth than the euro would.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Krystof Chamonikolas, Kriti Gupta

media:content.media:description: Ales Michl in Prague, on June 10. Photographer: Milan Jaros/Bloomberg

item.title: Biotech Firm MediLink Is Said to Hire Banks for Hong Kong IPO
item.description: MediLink Therapeutics Ltd. has hired China International Capital Corp., JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Morgan Stanley for a planned initial public offering in Hong Kong, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Pei Li, Julia Fioretti

media:content.media:description: MediLink Therapeutics Ltd. is exploring a licensing partnership to develop an antibody-drug conjugate with a global pharmaceutical company. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov

item.title: Bloomberg: The Asia Trade 11/6/25
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Tokyo and Sydney with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China’s Resort Island Hainan Braces for First Typhoon of Season
item.description: Hainan Island is bracing for the first typhoon of the season in the western Pacific, with the storm expected to dump heavy rain across parts of southern China as the system nears the coast.
item.dc:creator: Mary Hui

item.title: Japan’s Longer Debt Attractive for Foreigners, Morgan Stanley Says
item.description: Foreign investors are looking with interest at longer-term Japanese bonds, while it remains uncertain when the government will adjust how much of the debt it sells, Morgan Stanley says.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Haidi Lun

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians cross an intersection in the Shibuya district of Tokyo, Japan, on Saturday, Aug. 10, 2024. Japan is scheduled to release its second-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Aug. 15. Photographer: Shiho Fukada/Bloomberg

item.title: Apollo: Trade Concern a Positive for Asia Private Credit
item.description: Apollo Global Management's Matthew Michelini says investors in Asia are now considering putting a portion of investment intended for the US into places like India and Australia. He speaks with Yvonne Man on the sidelines of the Bloomberg Invest conference in Hong Kong. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Crude Oil Declines as Traders Parse Signals on US Trade Policy
item.description: Oil fell for a second day, as traders digested a welter of headlines on US trade policy, including an appeal court ruling that US President Donald Trump can press on with his global tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: Liberty Lift Solutions LLC pumpjacks near Crane, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 15, 2025. The Permian Basin, a sprawling shale patch that lies beneath Texas and New Mexico, is North America's most prolific shale patch. Photographer: Justin Hamel/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea President Visits Stock Exchange He Pledged to Help Boost
item.description: South Korea’s newly elected President Lee Jae-myung made a high-profile visit to the nation’s main stock exchange, signaling a clear commitment to follow through on his pledges to boost the market.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin, Shinhye Kang

item.title: Falling Australian Iron Ore Quality Sparks Grade Benchmark Tweak
item.description: The iron ore industry’s key pricing benchmark for seaborne cargoes will be lowered as the quality of supplies from biggest exporter Australia worsens.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell

media:content.media:description: Iron ore poured into a cargo ship at Rio Tinto Group's port facility in Karratha, Western Australia, on Friday, 20th Oct , 2023. Rio Tinto Group, BHP Group Ltd. and Fortescue Metals Group Ltd. produce almost two-thirds of the world’s seaborne iron ore from Western Australia, and margins remain enviable. For the first time in a generation, though, the specter of disruption looms over mining’s most reliable profit generator.

item.title: GQG’s Jain Cuts AI Exposure on Data Center Woes, Backs Utilities
item.description: Rajiv Jain, manager of the $23 billion GQG Partners Emerging Markets Equity Fund, is trimming exposure to investments linked to artificial intelligence on concerns of waning data-center demand, while remaining bullish on utilities.
item.dc:creator: Carmeli Argana

item.title: Rapido’s Entry Into India’s Food Delivery Business Poses Threat to Swiggy and Zomato
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: Morgan Stanley WM Australia's Hill on Growth Strategy
item.description: Rebecca Hill, CEO of Morgan Stanley Wealth Management Australia, says wealth transfer and philanthropic restructuring efforts are key areas of focus for the business. She speaks exclusively with Haidi Stroud Watts on the sidelines of the annual Morgan Stanley Australia Summit on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Morgan Stanley Australia CEO on Business Outlook
item.description: Richard Wagner, CEO of Morgan Stanley Australia, discusses his outlook and growth strategy for the business, as he sees an uptick in M&A and IPO activity in the Australian market in the second half of 2025. He speaks exclusively with Haidi Stroud Watts on the sidelines of the annual Morgan Stanley Australia Summit on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Taiwan to Restrict Hostile Takeovers in Crowded Financial Sector
item.description: Taiwan regulators announced plans to effectively block hostile takeovers in the island’s crowded financial sector, months after preventing a roughly $4.1 billion deal that would have created Taiwan’s largest financial group.
item.dc:creator: Betty Hou, Cindy Wang

item.title: Hong Kong's Chan Says IPO Pipeline Is 'Very Strong'
item.description: Hong Kong Financial Secretary Paul Chan says the IPO pipeline is "very strong" and that the "central authorities are very supportive" of mainland Chinese companies coming to the city for listings. He speaks on stage with David Ingles at Bloomberg Invest. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Warner Bros. Bonds Cut to Junk by Moody’s After Split Plan
item.description: Moody’s Ratings has downgraded debt issued by units of Warner Bros. Discovery Inc., adding another complication to the media giant’s discussions with bondholders after it announced plans to split in two.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr Flynn

media:content.media:description: Photo by Aleksander Kalka/NurPhoto via Getty Images) Photographer: NurPhoto/NurPhoto

item.title: Main China Steel Group Warns EV Price War Is Punishing Mills
item.description: China’s main steel industry group has warned an electric vehicle price war is hurting mills and deepening their financial woes.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Gemmell, Winnie Zhu

item.title: Michael Saylor Blasts Jim Chanos for Call to Short Strategy
item.description: Strategy’s Michael Saylor dismissed short-seller Jim Chanos’s recommendation to short the shares of the Bitcoin treasury company and buy the cryptocurrency because of the large premium the company’s common stock commands over the value of its token holdings.
item.dc:creator: David Pan, Katie Greifeld

media:content.media:description: Michael Saylor, co-founder and executive chairman of MicroStrategy Inc., during the Bitcoin 2025 conference in Las Vegas, Nevada, US, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. The event will examine Bitcoin's evolving global impact, with speakers from education, policy, finance, and technology. Photographer: Ronda Churchill/Bloomberg

item.title: Ares Seeks More Than $2 Billion for Asia Special Situations Fund
item.description: Ares Management Corp. is raising another Asia special situations fund to bolster its credit investments in the region, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Lulu Yilun Chen

media:content.media:description: Photo by Ying Tang/NurPhoto via Getty Images) Photographer: NurPhoto/NurPhoto

item.title: Traders See Cooling US-China Tensions Sparking Cautious Gains
item.description: Asia’s traders mostly shrugged off news of a preliminary US-China trade deal, with most looking for more details from the accord before making investment plans.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hsu

item.title: China Nudges Pig Farmers to Restrain Supply After Prices Slump
item.description: China is seeking to control hog numbers and curb pork production, in a bid to support prices of the country’s favorite meat and ease deflationary pressures in the economy.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Gu

item.title: US and China Agree Plan to Restore Trade Truce
item.description: The US and China agreed to a preliminary plan to ease trade tensions, which could revive the flow of sensitive goods between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Annmarie Hordern

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick at Lancaster House in London on June 10.
